sweetestcara: The fact that the "Africanness" of these people remained despite centuries of being out of Africa, to me is the victory over slavery. I'm just crying. That woman is definitely IGBO. God bless Cartegena. God bless Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
chiamaka_c_o: Doing us proud. Keep it up sis.
whore_de_culture: As you know, Cartagena was the largest slave market. Though it is a colonial town, and very beautiful, it is very African/Caribbean. Blacks are not treated well in Colombia in general but at least they are visible in Cartagena.... very few will you see in Bogota. But perhaps things will change.
whitney.cordoba: Yo no me voy, aquí me quedo. Esta tierra es mía, aquí me quedo 🎶 It's really fascinating how our traditions remain the same all over the world even though we've been apart for so many generations. Viva Colombia, Viva Nigeria ❤️

caribbeanunfiltered: For those who want to know what the song says: It is an afro-colombian song about identity and belonging. The translation:I'm not leaving, I'm staying here, I'm not leaving, I'm BoquilleroThis land is mine, I'm here to raise chickens, pigs and sheep. How beautiful are the walls and beaches of Cartagena What beautiful are the walls and beaches of Cartagena The one who arrives is fixed, the one who arrives stays. I'm not leaving, I'm staying here, I'm not leaving, I'm BoquilleroThis land is mine, I'm here to raise chickens, pigs and sheep. I am black, Afro-descendant. I am black, Afro-descendant. I want you to listen to my people. I'm not leaving, I'm staying here, I'm not leaving, I'm BoquilleroThis land is mine, I'm staying hereA raising chickens, pig and sheep
